text.text: London Tourism Pack

Prep those sandwiches, wash the stale whisky out the Thermos flask and pack that selfie stick, because you're about to embark on a whirlwind adventure. This is our definitive tourism pack: a selection of the iconic, tourist-ridden London experiences actually worth doing. 

Whilst a lot of what tourists do doesn't make much sense, some of it makes a great deal of sense. This is a longlist perfect for when that annoying American friend comes to stay and starts whining about Madame Tussauds.
1. Kew Gardens

tip.text:
We'll stick our necks on the line here and say that Kew Gardens is the most beautiful patch of greenery in the whole of London. It might be a schlep to get to, but once there those eyes, so used to the grey and the mundane, will find themselves treated to every conceivable bit of natural magic to grow out the ground. This is a truly wholesome, holistic day trip and something you must visit.

There's the iconic Victorian glasshouse housing a multi-country rainforest; an arboretum with over 14,000 trees; a treeptop walkway, a multi-sensory Hive installation exploring the life of bees; multiple conservatories full of exotic plants and cacti; and a Japanese landscaped garden. There are also rather expensive cafes and restaurants for the eating/drinking part of the day. Conservation is at the heart of everything Kew does, too, if you have enough morality left to care about something like that.

text.text: It might be a schlep to get to, but sometimes you've gotta travel for the good stuff - and Kew Gardens really is the good stuff. Here you can wonder through a Victorian glasshouse serving as a rainforest, hot conservatories brimming with cacti, an arebetum of some 14,000 trees and even stroll above the canopy on a treetop walkway. It's a vast oasis of all things natural and green that makes for the most calming and enriching of day trips.
2. Dim Sum in ChinaTown

tip.text:
This cute little no frills cafe is a popular Chinatown hangout for the youth (that's us by the way). You can't help but have a soft spot for its pleasing green facade, reasonable prices and generally rough and ready look. And we know those dumplings are made fresh each day 'cause we stood at the window and watched them at it - perhaps for too long.

If you know what's good for you you'll be ordering spicy pork and cabbage pan fried dumplings. Once they've been plonked down in front o' ya (don't expect a smile you old softy) you'll be wanting to dip them in a combination of chilli oil, soy and vinegar. If it's comfort you're after - wontons in broth it is. The chicken broth might be your standard offering but if you're looking for that Chinese childhood nostalgia hit you're onto a winner. There's tea to be had too - classics, greens, floral types (we liked chrysanthemum and honey) and bubble.

text.text: Finding yourself cast adrift in Chinatown without a clear plan can break the biggest and baddest - we've seen it with our very eyes/via the camera on your smartphone. But if you know where to go and embrace the charged chaos of this unique pocket of Central, you can have some delicious and authentic dim sum here for a nice price. Combine that comforting indulgence with a matinee show in the West End and you can rightly consider that a day well spent.
Click here for our guide to Chinatown
3. V&A

tip.text:
You've got your institutions, and then the next level is Victoria & Albert Museum: one of the largest museums in the world dedicated to decorative art and design. Someone once likened it to 'an extremely capacious handbag' and that seems kinda fitting. There are over 145 galleries across seven floors full of all sorts: furniture, ceramics, sculpture, paintings, posters, metalwork, glass, textiles and dress. They're divided into four main departments: 1) Asia, 2) Furniture, Textiles and Fashion, 3) Sculpture, Metalwork, Ceramics and Glass, and 4) Word & Image.

There are really so many wonders here that it's hard to know where to start, but definitely worth a look is the Cast Courts, two huge galleries dedicated to casts of post-classical European sculpture and the lavish gallery cafe. You could spend all day at this place perusing the free collections and not even have seen a third of it. So you may well have to come back.

text.text: The South Ken strip might be a blur of overpriced sandwiches, french accents and red trousers, but it also holds the V&A: a seven-floor jewel of decorative art and design in a huge building brimming with grandeur. By all means go and see some art or sculpture, but don't leave without kicking it for a bit it in the lavish gallery cafe which is a rarefied taste of the high life. Warning: you may have to push pensioners out the way to secure a seat.
4. A Day in Greenwich

tip.text: Explore infinity and beyond at London's only planetarium. Perched atop the hill at Greenwich Park in the Royal Observatory, this is the ideal day out for space cadets and the astro-curious. Meet our galaxy neighbours at special shows, or see the greatest show of all - the sky, daily at 11:45 and 4:15.

text.text:
It might require a three hour flight and visa*, but a day in Greenwich is a welcome dose of escapism: it really does feel like a quaint village here with cobbled streets, independent shops and lots of greenery. A UNESCO World Heritage Site, you can embark on a tour of the UNIVERSE! at the Planetarium, peruse the abundant market, or cotch in the beautiful Greenwich Park which has, for our money, the best view of the whole city. You can also get a picture at the GMT line if you so wish. 

*Inaccurate
Check our Area Guide to Greenwich
5. Shakespeare's Globe

tip.text:
Surely you've wandered past the strange white cylindrical structure on the Southbank and pondered what it's all about. Well it's Shakespeare's Globe, a faithful reconstruction of the classic Elizebethan playhouse where young Billy Shakespeare tried out his wondrous productions on the world. It dates all the way back to... 1997, which is not that old although several earlier incarnations burnt down.

There are a couple of theatres that put on Shakespearean productions often with contemporary twists to make it accessible for all - music to the ears to anyone forced to study Two Gentleman of Verona. Inside, it's a mighty impressive space and the standing stalls tickets are quite cheap, although standing for a play is not the most fun thing ever.

text.text:
The iconic Shakespeare's Globe, around since...1997. Okay, it's not that old but it is a faithful, beautiful reconstruction of the classic Elizebethan playhouse where underrated playwright Billy Shakespeare tried out his productions on the world. 

The plays staged here often put contemporary twists on the classics, which is music to the ears of anyone forced to study Two Gentleman of Verona at some point. Inside, it's a mighty impressive space and the standing stalls tickets are pretty cheap, although standing for a play is not the most fun thing ever.
6. Barbican Centre

tip.text:
Voted ‘London’s Ugliest Building’ in a 2003 poll, it seems that we haven’t been able to trust the British public long before the Brexit vote. This concrete Ziggurat is a mecca for all Brutalist architecture lovers, playing host to classical & contemporary music concerts, theatre performances, film screenings and art exhibitions. It also houses a humongous public library and a conservatory that is nothing short of a tropical oasis. Well, this is the largest arts centre in Europe we're talking about.

Have a mooch on in and be greeted to big industrial spaces equipped with high ceilings, artificial lighting, and the odd inconspicuous chair to sit back and absorb the raw ambience. Not the usual flouncy decoration, but they let their exhibitions do the talking. If you’re under 25 be sure to sign up to their free Young Barbican membership programme, which knocks the price of their exhibitions and film screenings to £5. Don’t say we don’t look out for ya.

text.text: It's everyone's favourite brutalist bae, Barbican Centre. After a strong PR campaign to make Brutalism popular again, Europe's largest cultural centre certainly draws the cool crowd, but the cool crowd is onto something here. Within its concrete confines you'll find cinemas, a tropical conservatory, a concert hall, a theatre, an art gallery, and numerous spaces to eat or just jam. We'd suggest getting lost along the concrete walkways before finding yourself at their outdoor fountains, preferably with a cold one in hand.
7. Boating on the Serpentine

tip.text: People have been dipping their toes, feet and the rest in the Serpentine for over 100 years so we're not about to argue. It's 100m (!) of open water swimming that's pretty popular with serious swimmers who aren't into the whole chlorine thing. It's only open to us plebs from May to September, thereafter you have to be part of their club.

text.text: Nothing quite screams 'TOURIST' like Hyde Park, aka the London Serengeti, apparently designed by Ken Livingstone as a trap where wealthy Americans would be unable to find their way out and forced to spend loads of cash. Yet head to the Serpentine on a sunny day with a picnic in your bag, grab a boat for £12 and head out on the water. Then try telling us you're not enjoying yourself - we won't believe it.
8. Take a walking tour

tip.text: For guided walks in the city, London Walks are the market leaders - so dominant that we're a little suspicious of foul play. Their strategy, as you might expect, is straight forward: they get someone that is super knowledgeable on a certain topic, and able to communicate that knowledge, to take curious strollers on a tour. But it's the breadth of topics explored which is kinda intriguing: Spies of Hampstead, Brunel's London, Urban Geology and the London of Oscar Wilde are amongst the variations. Tickets are £10.

text.text:
A guided walk might not be the sexiest thing you've ever heard, especially when you find out you have to pay £10 up front for these ones, ruling out the possibility of craftily sneaking off at the end without paying. But put yourself in the knowledgeable hands of one of the engrossing guides of London Walks and let them take you on a (sedate and informing) ride. 

Their two hour walks cover all sorts of topics: from the classics (Jack the Ripper, Westminster) to the slightly more niche (Brunel's London, Literary London). This is all about storytelling, and who doesn't like hearing a story?
9. Bagels on Brick Lane

tip.text:
Yeah, yeah, yeah, everyone knows about Beigel Bake - after all it is a Brick Lane institution and the bees knees of bagels. The shop is open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week so you can get your bagel fix round the clock. They serve their rings of dough traditional Jewish-style with fillings such as salmon and cream cheese, chopped herring, and salami. And all these come in below the £2 mark, which is an absolutely bargain.

The speciality, however, is the hot salt beef with mustard and pickles, and it'll set you back a relatively steep £4.50. But for the amount of salt beef they cram into that bad boy, it still feels like a deal. Just be prepared to queue, these bagels are famous and will draw a crowd.

text.text: Brick Lane is one hot mess: a riotous cacophony of leather jackets, wide-eyed tourists and Indian curry house barterers doing their best Pied Piper impressions. The bagel shops on this stretch are famous for a reason and Beigel Bake is our favourite. It's open 24 hours, pushing out thousands of delicious bagels a day that are stuffed full of hot salt beef with mustard or cream cheese and salmon, costing only a few pounds. Punters queue up in a fast moving line to get their bite, and the staff do not give fucks of any description.
10. Tate Modern late

tip.text:
The Tate Modern is the queen bee of the UK’s modern art scene. Housed in the former Bankside Power Station, this iconic institution has Picasso, Rothko, Pollock, Warhol, Dali & Matisse all under one roof (and free of charge). Mosey on in and be met by the sheer vastness of the Turbine Hall, a gigantic space that runs the length of the entire building. Try not to be overwhelmed - the Tate Modern is a serious feat and one needs to remain level-headed.

The gallery has numerous free collections, all organised by themes rather than chronological order. There's also 2 major temporary exhibitions that are ticketed (but usually worth the dollar). When staring at modern art trying to be profound and shiz gets a bit tiresome, the view from the top floor of the Switch House is first-class. Expect London’s skyline in all its glory (and a little bit of noseying into the living rooms of the rich & soulless).

text.text:
The unofficial queen bee of London's contemporary art scene, Tate Modern is a pretty overwhelming place. Housed in the former Bankside Power Station, the vastness of the building itself could provide plenty of intrigue but, as you're here, we guess you should probably see some art. 

Whilst the special exhibitions are undoubtedly momentous, important, pivotal and other similarly strong adjectives, they are also expensive and there are several really good free collections to scope. Our tip: come late on Fridays or Saturdays when you can enjoy the vastness of this place minus the crowds.
11. Hampstead Heath Ponds

tip.text:
If you've ever found yourself in Hampstead Heath on a warm day, you'll know the bathing ponds attract people like nothing else. And there's a reason for that: it's a delightful place to get back to nature and cool off - and we really do mean cool off, the water here is goddamn cold.

Originally dammed off clay pits, there are three 3 swimming ponds: mixed, female and male which are surrounded by willow trees, woodland and cruisers (the male pond). Jump in, have a swim, then dry off on the grassy banks - if you can find a space.

text.text: On the first hot day of the year, something strange happens near Hampstead Heath: a strong force-field emerges, sucking every conscious Londoner who owns a pair of skimpy speedos to the bathing ponds. Originally dammed-off clay pits, the three swimming ponds here are surrounded by willow trees, woodland and occasionally cruisers. The water is goddamn cold but real invigorating - it's the best location we've found for cooling off somewhere pretty.
12. Seeing the Thames via the Clipper

tip.text:
Boats on the Thames bring flashbacks of goddamn awful techno cruises that you literally cannot leave. But there are other ways to do it, and whilst the Thames Clipper might seem a little touristy, put those worries in a sack because the Clipper is potentially the easiest, most practical way to see the sights of the old river Thames.

We're talking Houses of Parliament, Shakespeare’s Globe, Tate Modern, Shard, Tower of London and Old Royal Naval College. There are loads of different tickets you can get but we suggest the 'Hop on Hop Off' deal coming in at around £17, that you can use all day.

text.text: Ignore those traumatic flashbacks of awful techno cruises that you couldn't leave; the Thames Clipper is the easiest, most practical way of seeing the sights of the River Thames. Y'know: the Houses of Parliament; Tate Modern; the Tower of London; floating dead pigeons. There are loads of different tickets you can get but we suggest the 'Hop on Hop Off' deal coming in at around £17 that you can use all day.
13. Colombia Road Flower Market

tip.text: An oasis of foliage and flowers with everything from bedding plants to 10 foot banana trees up for grabs. This is the perfect place to come freshen up your home on a Sunday, all in prep for the week ahead. Alongside the Sunday market you'll find a host of independent galleries and shops selling pottery, perfume and the like.

text.text: Come Sunday in Hackney, all manner of well-dressed sorts mooch along to the iconic Columbia Road flower market as a normally quiet, cobbled road becomes a heaving hustling oasis of foliage, flowers and fired up cockney's barking out offers. It's a vigorous shaking of the senses that has the eyes, nose and ears in a daze of stimulation. But crucially, you can get some really nice flowers here for cheap.
14. Sir John Soane

tip.text: Left exactly as it was when he died, the house of 19th century architect John Soane is a three-house-wide labyrinth of curiosities. On display are an incredible array of famous artworks, sculptures, furniture and artefacts. If you have limited time be sure to check out the sarcophagus of the Egyptian king and the picture room in which the famous painted series 'The Rake's Progress' by William Hogarth hangs. But don't come with limited time - everything is worth swooning over for quite a while. Plus it's all free, bro.

text.text: The 19th century architect John Soane was a pretty good sort: along with designing the Bank of England and Dulwich Picture Gallery, he created a labyrinth-like house of curiosities filled with architectural gems, artwork, furniture and artefacts from all over the world. Each room is its own jumbled, seemingly chaotic, work of art - he wanted this place to encourage learning and wonder and it's packed full of shit to have you swooning.
15. Vintage shopping at Portobello Market

tip.text:
Iconic, bustling and colourful, Portobello Road Market is a true testament to the history and people of London. Although the area’s gentrification over the past decade or so has seen a shift in the vibe towards the more upmarket, it remains a wonderful and worthy destination.

Crazy market day is Saturday: expect flocks of tourists seeking out the blue door from ‘Notting Hill’ and a motley crew of Portobello’s eclectic characters busking, conversing and wandering about. Arrive hungry and have your pick of the vying vendors, from paella to pancakes, and explore the shops and stalls at your leisure. Whether you’re after classic vinyl, antique jewellery, vintage clothing or that ephemeral “je ne sais quoi,” this famous and historic market is the perfect place to look. Look out for the Moroccan fish stall on Golborne Road - it's killing it.

text.text: If vintage threads are what you're after, then Portobello Road Market is still the place to head. Crazy market day is Saturday, but we'd suggest Friday if you can make it, with the flocks of tourists a little less dense leaving you able to more easily spot Portobello's eclectic characters busking and conversing. And the Moroccan fish stall on Golborne Road is where to eat.
